transcript:
Therapist: You mentioned earlier that you've been struggling with your positive data log and gathering evidence against your negative core beliefs. Can you tell me more about what's been challenging for you in that process?

Patient: I think the hardest part is just remembering to do it. When I'm feeling down, it's like I have blinders on and can only see the negative. It's hard to think of any evidence that goes against my negative beliefs.

Therapist: That's a great observation. When we're feeling depressed, it's common to have a negativity bias, where we tend to focus on information that confirms our negative beliefs and filter out information that contradicts them. That's why the positive data log can be such a powerful tool - it helps us intentionally seek out evidence that challenges our negative beliefs, even when it feels hard to see.

One strategy that can help with remembering to use the positive data log is to pair it with a daily habit or routine. For example, you could make it a habit to write down one piece of evidence against your negative core beliefs every night before bed, or every morning when you first wake up. You could even set a reminder on your phone to help you remember.

Patient: That's a good idea. I like the thought of making it part of my daily routine. I think I'll try setting a reminder on my phone and see if that helps me remember to do it more consistently.

Therapist: Great! I'm glad that strategy resonates with you. Another thing that can help with the positive data log is to get more specific about the types of evidence you're looking for. Sometimes, when our negative core beliefs are very broad, like "I'm not worthy of acceptance and belonging," it can be hard to know where to start in terms of gathering evidence against them.

One way to make it more manageable is to break it down into smaller, more specific beliefs that contribute to the overall core belief. For example, you might have a related belief like, "I'm not good at my job, so I don't deserve to be accepted by my colleagues." That's a bit more specific, and it gives you a clearer idea of what kind of evidence to look for - in this case, examples of times when you have done well at your job or been accepted by your colleagues.

Patient: That makes sense. I can see how breaking it down into smaller beliefs would make it easier to find evidence against them. I guess I just worry that the evidence I come up with won't feel "valid" enough, like I'll be tricking myself into thinking things are better than they really are.

Therapist: That's a common concern. It's important to remember that the goal of the positive data log isn't to "trick" yourself into thinking everything is perfect, or to ignore real challenges or areas for growth. The goal is to develop a more balanced and realistic view of yourself and your experiences, one that acknowledges both your strengths and your areas for improvement.

It might help to think of it this way: even if you make a mistake or face a challenge at work, that doesn't mean you're fundamentally unworthy of acceptance and belonging. It just means you're human, like everyone else. The evidence you gather in your positive data log can help remind you of that fact, even when your negative core beliefs are telling you otherwise.

Patient: I can see how that would be helpful. I guess I just need to practice looking for that evidence, even when it feels hard.

Therapist: Absolutely. And remember, you don't have to do this perfectly. Even small pieces of evidence can add up over time to help shift your overall perspective. And we can keep working on this together in our sessions, so you don't have to do it all on your own.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. That's reassuring to know. I feel like I have a better understanding of how to use the positive data log now.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that. And remember, if you have any questions or challenges come up as you're using the positive data log, we can always discuss them in our sessions. That's what I'm here for.

Patient: Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll definitely let you know if I run into any issues.

Therapist: Great. So, to recap: you're going to try setting a daily reminder to use your positive data log, and focus on gathering evidence against more specific negative beliefs related to your overall core belief of "I'm not worthy of acceptance and belonging." Does that sound right?
